Post Description:
A very lively atmosphere greeted me at Tampines North Primary yesterday. Thank you for the warm welcome #backtoschool! 

Met some P5 and 6 students who shared their #CircuitBreaker experience with me. They didn‚Äôt like it and much preferred going to school. But they also learnt to make the most of the situation. Some picked up new skills, while others helped out with household chores. They spent more time with family members and learnt to appreciate the important things in life. They showed adaptability and resilience and these are the traits that will put them in good stead for the future. Very proud of our young ones!
Comments: You are doing a good job üòä

Post Description:
Working from home has taken new meaning for most of us. We‚Äôre doing more remote meetings with our colleagues and realising that we can be just as productive at home as we have been in the office. The circuit breaker has showed us that we can work effectively in different ways.
We must now embrace working from home as the new norm. So even as more Singaporeans return to work during Phase 1 of the reopening plans, we expect the majority of the workforce to continue to work from home. 
This is why we have imposed the following requirement on employers after 1 June: your staff should return to work only if they need specialised equipment and machinery that cannot be accessed from home, or if they need to fulfil legal requirements (eg to complete contracts or transactions). On that basis, we expect most employees working in an office setting to continue working from home as they are presently doing. 
Many employers and managers will need to adjust their mindsets to this new normal. It‚Äôs no longer about having all your staff physically present at work. Even if they have to be on site, consider if they really need to do so every day. You could have hybrid arrangements where your employees work from home several days a week. 
For those who absolutely need to be in the office, employers must ensure that the work environment is safe (eg maintain good ventilation and high hygiene standards, and have officers seated apart etc) and offer them staggered work hours. 
All these workplace measures are critical in our fight against Covid-19 - they will reduce the need for daily movement of people, and minimise the risks of the virus flaring up again.
Comments: üëçüòäüí™ Have a good Long weekend.

Post Description:
We are making progress in controlling the outbreak. The daily infection numbers in the community have been coming down steadily.  In recent days, the number of daily new community cases has been at single digits. If this continues over the next two weeks, we will be in a good position to consider easing on some of the circuit breaker measures after 1 June, but in a careful and calibrated manner.

Note: Table shows the average daily cases over the various time periods, and across different categories

Post Description:
We are making progress in controlling the outbreak. The daily infection numbers in the community have been coming down steadily. Note: Table shows the average daily cases over the various time periods, and across different categories
Comments: @lawrencewongst Mr Wong, I respect you the most out of all the ministers who make up the Covid taskforce, and am generally assured with you heading the team. However  the key question to ask here is - does it make sense to virtually lockdown the entire country for extended number of weeks, when we have seen clearly that the average number of community cases is only from single digits to the high teens for awhile now? Singaporeans and businesses alike have been on the receiving end of the strict measures put in place, through entirely no fault of theirs. While the foreign worker dormitories oversight is unfortunate, trying to overcompensate for an earlier mistake with excessively draconian measures is not the way to go. The risk and reward trade-offs here are clearly unbalanced.

Post Description:
Seniors are significantly more at risk from Covid-19. Globally, 80% of Covid-related deaths occur in older persons above 60. In Singapore it is 95%. Many young people with Covid-19 have mild symptoms. But for seniors the disease is severe and potentially life-threatening. 
That‚Äôs why we are stepping up our precautions at residential care homes serving the elderly. We are putting in place tighter infection controls and prevention practices. We are requiring all resident-facing staff to stay onsite or at designated hotels during the circuit breaker period. We are also testing all 30k residents and staff of these homes - not just once, but on a periodic basis every two weeks. 
At the same time, all of us can do our part to protect the seniors in our families. Remind them to stay home as much as possible and minimise contacts with others. If the seniors are living with us, then help them with their errands, so that they can minimise their movement outside. If the seniors are living elsewhere, then stay in touch with them with frequent phone calls, so that they will not feel socially isolated. 
Safeguarding the welfare of our seniors is a collective effort. We must do everything we can to keep our seniors safe through this crisis.
Comments: Sir lawrence, you have always have my respect throughout this covid fight, and i and my family has been in this fight by doing all that is required of us dutifully in order not to weigh on our healthcare frontline. We are appreciative and grateful for all the great decisions so far. However, i am indeed shocked that in the last few days your team has said to protect the most vulnerable group in nursing homes as they will not be able to survive well if the virus hits them. Why then is MOH allowing covid patients to be housed in Renci community where there is so many levels of vulnerable residents and also patients who need to come for weekly kidney dialysis? These group has bodies that cannot take a second round of strike against them. Could you be kind and just and not remove this post and instead look into this matter, and give it serious considerations if its a right decision, and if this contradicts the stand to protect the most vulnerable ones among us? They have family who loves them till their last breath. This last breath is already a vulnerable last one and one wrong move will not be a just a number, it will be shattered family hearts. We sincerely hope you will look into this. We understand bed crunches issues, but please underdtand us, we the family of the vulnerable residents, need to seek ur help to protect the most vulnerable ones. A 1% outbreak might become their 99% death. To house covid newr healthy ones is acceptable, to house near critically vulnerable ones is a decision that is not wise at all.

Post Description:
We are seeing some results from the circuit breaker but these are still early days and we cannot let up. We must hunker down and push harder to break the transmission chain decisively. 
First, we call on everyone to minimise movement. Stay home as much as possible. If you need to go out to buy food or groceries, do so by yourself.  If you need to go out to exercise, do so by yourself and in your neighbourhood. This is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones.
Second, we will tighten access to popular areas where people are still gathering, like wet markets and supermarkets, so that safe distancing measures can be better implemented. For a start we will introduce a new control measure in selected popular wet markets to limit entry to alternate days.
Third we will close more work premises and tighten the list of essential services. The aim is to reduce the number of essential workers still out and about, so that we can minimise movement and interactions. Additional requirements will also be put in place to ensure that these workers and their employers uphold safe distancing measures at their workplaces. 
We will implement the above measures from now till 4 May. Beyond that we will have to extend the circuit breaker for another four weeks till 1 June. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and if we are able to bring down our community infection numbers decisively, then we can consider easing some of the measures gradually. 
I thank all Singaporeans and residents who have made tremendous efforts and sacrifices to observe the circuit breaker measures so far. We are asking more from everyone now. We are mindful of the impact, and the government will continue to help employers and workers through the extended circuit breaker period. Ultimately this is a test of our unity, resilience and resolve. If we all do our part, we can stamp out the virus and overcome this together.
Comments: Thank you for your leadership üôèüèª

Post Description:
We are seeing some results from the circuit breaker but these are still early days and we cannot let up. We must hunker down and push harder to break the transmission chain decisively. 
First, we call on everyone to minimise movement. Stay home as much as possible. If you need to go out to buy food or groceries, do so by yourself.  If you need to go out to exercise, do so by yourself and in your neighbourhood. This is the best way to protect yourself and your loved ones.
Second, we will tighten access to popular areas where people are still gathering, like wet markets and supermarkets, so that safe distancing measures can be better implemented. For a start we will introduce a new control measure in selected popular wet markets to limit entry to alternate days.
Third we will close more work premises and tighten the list of essential services. The aim is to reduce the number of essential workers still out and about, so that we can minimise movement and interactions. Additional requirements will also be put in place to ensure that these workers and their employers uphold safe distancing measures at their workplaces. 
We will implement the above measures from now till 4 May. Beyond that we will have to extend the circuit breaker for another four weeks till 1 June. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and if we are able to bring down our community infection numbers decisively, then we can consider easing some of the measures gradually. 
I thank all Singaporeans and residents who have made tremendous efforts and sacrifices to observe the circuit breaker measures so far. We are asking more from everyone now. We are mindful of the impact, and the government will continue to help employers and workers through the extended circuit breaker period. Ultimately this is a test of our unity, resilience and resolve. If we all do our part, we can stamp out the virus and overcome this together.
Comments: Sir, some of us are still working in CBD area üò¢ help help

We will implement the above measures from now till 4 May. Beyond that we will have to extend the circuit breaker for another four weeks till 1 June. We will continue to monitor the situation closely and if we are able to bring down our community infection numbers decisively, then we can consider easing some of the measures gradually. 
I thank all Singaporeans and residents who have made tremendous efforts and sacrifices to observe the circuit breaker measures so far. We are asking more from everyone now. We are mindful of the impact, and the government will continue to help employers and workers through the extended circuit breaker period. Ultimately this is a test of our unity, resilience and resolve. If we all do our part, we can stamp out the virus and overcome this together.
Comments: A big thank you to your efforts during this difficult period #sgunited#staysafesingapore

Post Description:
It has been almost a week since the circuit breaker kicked in. I continue to receive a lot of feedback on the measures. I try to read all of them although I am unable to reply to them personally. Some say that it‚Äôs only a partial lockdown and prefer a full lockdown, which they think will be more effective. Others say the current measures are already too restrictive and causing mental and social problems for themselves and their families. 
I understand that there are some who genuinely find it hard to adjust. We will do our best to support them. But this is a public health crisis, and we have to do what is right and necessary to protect Singaporeans. In theory, we could keep most places open, so long as safe distancing measures are strictly adhered to. But increasingly we see that this is hard to achieve. So tougher measures are necessary. Yesterday, we closed off selected areas in our parks and nature reserves. Today we will be closing all beaches in Singapore.
Remember the bottom line is that all of us must drastically reduce our contact with others for the circuit breaker to be effective.  And we have to sustain this effort not just for a few days but till the end of the month at least. So stay home as much as possible. If you absolutely must go out (eg for food or groceries), keep a safe distance from others, wear a mask, and go home once you are done. 
The health of all Singaporeans depends on each one of us. We will get through this together.
Comments: Naysayers can say what they want but being a leader of a nation is not just with a quick snap of fingers. So thank you for the work done!

Post Description:
It has been almost a week since the circuit breaker kicked in. I continue to receive a lot of feedback on the measures. I try to read all of them although I am unable to reply to them personally. Some say that it‚Äôs only a partial lockdown and prefer a full lockdown, which they think will be more effective. Others say the current measures are already too restrictive and causing mental and social problems for themselves and their families. 
I understand that there are some who genuinely find it hard to adjust. We will do our best to support them. But this is a public health crisis, and we have to do what is right and necessary to protect Singaporeans. In theory, we could keep most places open, so long as safe distancing measures are strictly adhered to. But increasingly we see that this is hard to achieve. So tougher measures are necessary. Yesterday, we closed off selected areas in our parks and nature reserves. Today we will be closing all beaches in Singapore.
Remember the bottom line is that all of us must drastically reduce our contact with others for the circuit breaker to be effective.  And we have to sustain this effort not just for a few days but till the end of the month at least. So stay home as much as possible. If you absolutely must go out (eg for food or groceries), keep a safe distance from others, wear a mask, and go home once you are done. 
The health of all Singaporeans depends on each one of us. We will get through this together.

It has been almost a week since the circuit breaker kicked in. I continue to receive a lot of feedback on the measures. I try to read all of them although I am unable to reply to them personally. Some say that it‚Äôs only a partial lockdown and prefer a full lockdown, which they think will be more effective. Others say the current measures are already too restrictive and causing mental and social problems for themselves and their families. 
I understand that there are some who genuinely find it hard to adjust. We will do our best to support them. But this is a public health crisis, and we have to do what is right and necessary to protect Singaporeans. In theory, we could keep most places open, so long as safe distancing measures are strictly adhered to. But increasingly we see that this is hard to achieve. So tougher measures are necessary. Yesterday, we closed off selected areas in our parks and nature reserves. Today we will be closing all beaches in Singapore.
Remember the bottom line is that all of us must drastically reduce our contact with others for the circuit breaker to be effective.  And we have to sustain this effort not just for a few days but till the end of the month at least. So stay home as much as possible. If you absolutely must go out (eg for food or groceries), keep a safe distance from others, wear a mask, and go home once you are done. 
The health of all Singaporeans depends on each one of us. We will get through this together.
Comments: Thank you for all the hard work Minister Wong. I truly support this initiative. Better be a month than get extended ! Best just to ‚Äúsaman‚Äù , government has been too kind ! So much support from government yet to get people to co operate is like so difficult ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è ! The younger generation must educate our parents and grandparents... encourage them to stay at home . I explained to my mom about how this covid19 spread only then she fear to step out ! ü§™

Post Description:
It has been almost a week since the circuit breaker kicked in. I continue to receive a lot of feedback on the measures. I try to read all of them although I am unable to reply to them personally. Some say that it‚Äôs only a partial lockdown and prefer a full lockdown, which they think will be more effective. Others say the current measures are already too restrictive and causing mental and social problems for themselves and their families. 
I understand that there are some who genuinely find it hard to adjust. We will do our best to support them. But this is a public health crisis, and we have to do what is right and necessary to protect Singaporeans. In theory, we could keep most places open, so long as safe distancing measures are strictly adhered to. But increasingly we see that this is hard to achieve. So tougher measures are necessary. Yesterday, we closed off selected areas in our parks and nature reserves. Today we will be closing all beaches in Singapore.
Remember the bottom line is that all of us must drastically reduce our contact with others for the circuit breaker to be effective.  And we have to sustain this effort not just for a few days but till the end of the month at least. So stay home as much as possible. If you absolutely must go out (eg for food or groceries), keep a safe distance from others, wear a mask, and go home once you are done. 
The health of all Singaporeans depends on each one of us. We will get through this together.
Comments: Take good care of yourself & also all the Covid task force Ministers. The team‚Äôs 24/7 hard work has not gone unappreciated and unnoticed. A big thank you.

Post Description:
<Nation-wide Circuit Breaker>

The Taskforce has decided to put in place a nation-wide circuit breaker starting for at least a month, starting 7 April, to slow the spread of the virus. 
Under these stringent measures, all workplace premises other than those providing essential services or operating as part of global supply chains will have to close. For these closed premises, the work activities can continue only if all their employees work from home. Schools and IHLs will also be closed and will shift to full home-based learning.

Supermarkets and F&B outlets will remain open. For all F&B outlets, including hawker centres and coffeeshops, dining in will not be allowed - so you can only order food for delivery or takeout.

Essentially, we must all abide by these basic rules:
- Stay at Home. Avoid interactions with anyone outside of your family members who are already living with you
- Go out only if you have to do essential things (like going to work, buying groceries, or doing your daily exercise)
- If you have to go out, and cannot avoid close contact with others, wear a mask.

All of us now have a critical role to play in slowing the spread of the virus. Let us hunker down and beat the virus together.
Comments: Is OK. We fully understood and supportive...We knew u guys are racing with time and racing with resources... with all these tightened up measures are nothing and insignificant compared to our nurses and doctors plus ambulance workers and many more front line healthcare workers coz they too do have families too in time of fear, paranoid and dilemma...May GOD Bless them

Post Description:
<Nation-wide Circuit Breaker>

The Taskforce has decided to put in place a nation-wide circuit breaker starting for at least a month, starting 7 April, to slow the spread of the virus. 
Under these stringent measures, all workplace premises other than those providing essential services or operating as part of global supply chains will have to close. For these closed premises, the work activities can continue only if all their employees work from home. Schools and IHLs will also be closed and will shift to full home-based learning.

Supermarkets and F&B outlets will remain open. For all F&B outlets, including hawker centres and coffeeshops, dining in will not be allowed - so you can only order food for delivery or takeout.

Essentially, we must all abide by these basic rules:
- Stay at Home. Avoid interactions with anyone outside of your family members who are already living with you
- Go out only if you have to do essential things (like going to work, buying groceries, or doing your daily exercise)
- If you have to go out, and cannot avoid close contact with others, wear a mask.

All of us now have a critical role to play in slowing the spread of the virus. Let us hunker down and beat the virus together.
Comments: Dear Minister Wong, thank you and the team for your hard work. I‚Äôd like to add if I may - that is to make mask wearing mandatory when we are out. This is crucial especially in enclosed setting like buses, trains. It should not be a choice, left to the people to decide since the govt stand is - wear one if you can‚Äôt avoid crowds. There will always be  a group of people who don‚Äôt or refuses to wear one for their own reasons. Wearing one is protecting OTHERS  from one‚Äôs droplets from coughing, sneezing, talking. We should all and rightfully so, be concerned at the rise of local unlinked cases and the asymptomatic carriers lurking amongst us. We can‚Äôt afford to have a tiny chance that some of these people could be asymptomatic and unknowingly be spreading the virus. Now that every resident will get a reusable mask, there is no reason not to mask up when out. I hope people will change the selfish mindset - cloth mask ‚â† ineffective (against virus) therefore I won‚Äôt wear.  When Malaysia ends her lockdown we will see an influx of people coming in. Temperature scanning can not longer be trusted as a gauge to weed out the infected ones. We need everyone to wear a mask, on top of social distancing measures to further boost containment. Anyone not wearing one should be refused entry to Singapore. This rule should also be applied to trains and buses and crowded places. The seniors, and the sick are the most vulnerable group of people - we must all do what we can as citizens to protect them and to safeguard our healthcare system. Have a restful Sunday with your family Sir. SG United.

For these closed premises, the work activities can continue only if all their employees work from home. Schools and IHLs will also be closed and will shift to full home-based learning.

Supermarkets and F&B outlets will remain open. For all F&B outlets, including hawker centres and coffeeshops, dining in will not be allowed - so you can only order food for delivery or takeout.

Essentially, we must all abide by these basic rules:
- Stay at Home. Avoid interactions with anyone outside of your family members who are already living with you
- Go out only if you have to do essential things (like going to work, buying groceries, or doing your daily exercise)
- If you have to go out, and cannot avoid close contact with others, wear a mask.

All of us now have a critical role to play in slowing the spread of the virus. Let us hunker down and beat the virus together.
Comments: While the circuit breaker is in place, we should also implement universal testing (a local lab has devised a 5min rest with a 95% accuracy rate) and round up all Covid infected persons to maximise the effectiveness of cutting off viral transmission within the community... then once the month is up, we should legally mandate (and strictly enforce) all noses and mouths to be covered in public (once u step outta your house for no matter how long and for no matter what purpose)... this will enable us to embrace both defensive (semi-lockdown) and offensive (testing) measures in tandem to combat Covid so we can resume a greater semblance of domestic economic normalcy as soon as possible... the living conditions of our FWs also need urgent and significant improvement bcoz we're only as strong as our weakest link, and right now the FW dorms are looking pretty dodgy...

- If you have to go out, and cannot avoid close contact with others, wear a mask.

All of us now have a critical role to play in slowing the spread of the virus. Let us hunker down and beat the virus together.
Comments: Thank you for the hard work! We appreciate the rationale behind this. However, in implementing such measures, perhaps we may want to consider having outreach programmes to teach the older / less tech savvy members of the community how to place orders online, and likewise for the less tech savvy F&B outlet owners, how to get on board these platforms so they are not left behind.

Post Description:
<Nation-wide Circuit Breaker>

The Taskforce has decided to put in place a nation-wide circuit breaker starting for at least a month, starting 7 April, to slow the spread of the virus. 
Under these stringent measures, all workplace premises other than those providing essential services or operating as part of global supply chains will have to close. For these closed premises, the work activities can continue only if all their employees work from home. Schools and IHLs will also be closed and will shift to full home-based learning.

Supermarkets and F&B outlets will remain open. For all F&B outlets, including hawker centres and coffeeshops, dining in will not be allowed - so you can only order food for delivery or takeout.

Essentially, we must all abide by these basic rules:
- Stay at Home. Avoid interactions with anyone outside of your family members who are already living with you
- Go out only if you have to do essential things (like going to work, buying groceries, or doing your daily exercise)
- If you have to go out, and cannot avoid close contact with others, wear a mask.

All of us now have a critical role to play in slowing the spread of the virus. Let us hunker down and beat the virus together.
Comments: Much needed, i can see people buying grocery in large qty near Sheng siong jurong west jalan bahar.  But good to see two police officer outside ... üëç

Comments: Dear Minister, good evening. Please refers to Case 152 and Case 170. QUOTE CNA News Case 170 : The case is a 56-year-old Indonesian woman, believed to be an imported case.¬†She reported onset of symptoms while in Indonesia on Mar 6. She arrived in Singapore on Mar 9 and went to the Singapore General Hospital. She was diagnosed with COVID-19 on Mar 10 afternoon.¬†UNQUOTEThis Indonesian knew she had Covid-19 symptoms on 6 Mar and she intentionally fly to Singapore on 9 Mar ? Singapore cannot afford to be "a dumping ground for overseas Covid-19 carriers". Question : if she had symptoms , why was she allowed to board the plane to Singapore ? By doing so, we are putting our airline staff, airport staff, taxi staff, and many others at Changi Airport at "high exposure risk". What's the point if we spent so much resources and efforts in local containment and seeing some results with controlled increase of Covid-19 cases but then "all efforts go to waste" with these "imported cases dumped by themselves" into Singapore ? Something urgent needs to be done to curb this. Otherwise, Singapore cases may explode to be like the next Italy and South Korea. Even Beijing after seeing some results in their containment efforts is asking All Foreigners to be quarantied for 14 days upon arrival in Beijing.  Our approach should be : Do All Or Nothing. Since we are doing something about it, do try to do all to prevent Singapore becoming "a dumping ground for Covid-19 carriers" MOH starts charging short term visitors for Covid-19 treatment is the correct move, but more needs to be done. If Indonesians know or suspect they are Covid-19 carriers, they should seek treatment in Indonesia instead of flying around, moving around to increase the risk exposure to others. Kindly urgently look into this "loophole". Trust your wisdom and understanding on these. Thank you. @gankimyong@ongyekung@leehsienloong @hengsweekeat @khawboonwan

Read : JAKARTA: Mr Fachri Muchtar developed a cough and had difficulty breathing after staying in a packed lodging in Jakarta‚Äôs Old Town for an event in early March.He visited a referral hospital for COVID-19 in Jakarta on Sunday (Mar 15) and was immediately taken to the emergency ward for a blood test and X-ray. The 21-year-old university student was then led to a decontamination room with five other people, who were all coughing.By evening, his test results came back and he was told that he was a COVID-19 suspect patient.‚ÄúI was placed in another room with five other people. There were only three beds, so I had to sit in a wheelchair for the entire night.‚ÄúI was only given a bed the next morning,‚Äù he told CNA. Mr Muchtar waited until the afternoon before he was tested for COVID-19. ‚ÄúA cotton bud-like device was inserted into my nose to take a sample of my mucus,‚Äù he explained.He was told to go home and self-quarantine before returning to the hospital again on Tuesday afternoon for the second swab test.Mr Muchtar was among the 1,592 people who were tested for COVID-19 in Indonesia as of Wednesday, according to statistics on the Health Ministry‚Äôs website.National spokesperson for COVID-19 Achmad Yurianto said on Tuesday that the government is equipped with 10,000 test kits.The number of laboratories to test COVID-19 will also be increased to at least 12 nationwide next week from the existing four, he added Just two weeks ago - when Indonesia reported its¬†first COVID-19 cases¬†- only one laboratory in Jakarta was allowed to conduct such tests for the entire country.As the number of cases rose - the current tally stood at¬†277 with 19 deaths¬†- worried Indonesians showed up at the referral hospitals, hoping to get tested for COVID-19.Most have their symptoms checked and were turned away without taking the swab tests, leading to confusion and complaints ...(to be continued)

Comments: Dear Minister, good afternoon. Feedback : Why are Taiwan and Hong Kong as well as Macau faring better than other cities in tackling against the Covid-19 Crisis ? My guess : M A S K S . That's right. Almost everyone is encouraged to wear masks. So what happens when they do that ? Those who are infected or unaware they are affected covered themselves with masks thus reducing the risks of transmission. And those not infected also wear masks makes it a " double protection ". We cannot adopt a "self-deceiving" concept that asking everyone to wear masks will not help as much simply because we do not have enough masks or could not produce our own masks. Wearing masks does help. If not, why 1 minister said if we run out of masks, medical staff may not work? It simply means masks help the medical staff to protect themselves against the Covid-19. Or wearing masks is better than not wearing any. So after so much talk, main point ? Main Point : we study Macau Hong Kong Taiwan and we can gauge that encouraging everyong to wear masks help in the containment. Our Govt next task ? Quickly assemble a large scale production line that can produce our own masks at about 5 mil units per day rate. Any excess we can sell, export or donate to other countries who want them. By doing so, Singapore may also create some jobs for those who will work at the masks factory. Trust your wisdom that this feedback can be constructive enough to be seriously considered by your taskforce. Not least, thank you for your hardwork in your crisis tackling efforts. @khawboonwan @leehsienloong @hengsweekeat @gankimyong @ongyekung @teocheehean

Post Description:
The Wuhan coronavirus situation is evolving rapidly. Over the last 24 hours, we have seen an accelerating trend of infection among the population of Chinese nationals from Hubei. That‚Äôs why we have decided to take additional measures today to limit the risks from Hubei travellers. 
We will quarantine recent travellers from Hubei who are still in Singapore, as well as returning residents/long-term pass holders with recent travel history to Hubei. We will also take actions to curb new visitors with recent travel history to Hubei or with PRC passports issued in Hubei. 
We have a comprehensive plan with contingencies for different scenarios. These measures are part of our plans. Given the accelerating trends and risk levels, we‚Äôve decided to activate them now. 
We have to be mindful that the situation is fluid, with new information coming out from China every day, and with our risk assessments being updated constantly. So we will monitor closely and adjust our posture day by day. We are now taking stricter measure against Hubei travelers. If there is evidence of community spread in other Chinese cities or provinces, we will update our measures accordingly. 
There is so far no evidence of community spread in Singapore. So our actions are aimed at containment - to reduce the risk of such community spread. We will continue with our approach of vigilant monitoring and swift actions to protect Singaporeans.
Comments: Will the virus pass through swimming pools?

Post Description:
The Wuhan coronavirus situation is evolving rapidly. Over the last 24 hours, we have seen an accelerating trend of infection among the population of Chinese nationals from Hubei. That‚Äôs why we have decided to take additional measures today to limit the risks from Hubei travellers. 
We will quarantine recent travellers from Hubei who are still in Singapore, as well as returning residents/long-term pass holders with recent travel history to Hubei. We will also take actions to curb new visitors with recent travel history to Hubei or with PRC passports issued in Hubei. 
We have a comprehensive plan with contingencies for different scenarios. These measures are part of our plans. Given the accelerating trends and risk levels, we‚Äôve decided to activate them now.

Comments: This is a unique crisis and unfortunately there are little experience that can be drawn upon. The virus spreads quickly and it would be too late if actions and decisions are taken when the evidence of local spread emerges. In the face of this challenge, I believe Singaporeans are not as bothered to take the helicopter view how draconian measures will impact the economy. On the contrary, these extreme but brave decisions will present to us Singaporeans the comfort that our leaders (and 4G leaders) are defending their citizens at all costs. We hope the government will err and over react in such instance. Singaporeans will be delighted. The virus runs ahead of decisions that are made post evidence. So decisions must now attempt to move ahead of it.. or at least try

Post Description:
The air travel bubble, which would have allowed for leisure travel between the 2 sides, had been suspended indefinitely since November last year, after a spike in Covid-19 cases in Hong Kong.

Both cities had earlier agreed that the arrangement would be suspended if the 7-day average of unlinked coronavirus cases in either city exceeded 5. Hong Kong's figure currently stands at 4.57.

Link in bio @straits_times
#airtravelbubble #coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: Stay safe. Don∆í??t travel first. Health priority. Fun last.

Post Description:
Update: Singapore and Hong Kong have decided to defer the start of the air travel bubble to beyond this month given that the number of local unlinked cases in Hong Kong is still high, says CAAS.
The exact start date of the arrangement will be reviewed late this month.
The move comes as Hong Kong hunkers down under harsher social distancing measures in anticipation of what health authorities have warned could be the worst Covid-19 wave so far.
Hong Kong's daily new infections have crossed 70 for more than a week.
The spike was led initially by a growing dance club cluster of more than 500, most of whom are tai tais and their young dancing instructors.
Link in bio @straits_times
#travelbubble #hongkong #singapore #coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: @tomatotihitina I wish I could live here so bad

Post Description:
Update: Singapore and Hong Kong have decided to defer the start of the air travel bubble to beyond this month given that the number of local unlinked cases in Hong Kong is still high, says CAAS.

Link in bio @straits_times
#travelbubble #hongkong #singapore #coronavirus #covid19 #StraitsTimes
Comments: As 1 country it is easy to say what needs to get done and everyone toe the line. This takes some leadership foresight and a public who's generally willing to cooperate. Opening up a country to another? Unless both countries have the common same detection, tracing, control methods and direction (just like 1 country) setting measurements to determine when to pull the plug is not enough. Are the countries in a travel bubble willing to adapt and adjust to each other for a common way forward- just like a single country's response, containment and treatment methods? Are the people of both countries trusting enough of the other? If not, then travel bubbles anywhere would be some way off.

Update: Singapore and Hong Kong have decided to defer the start of the air travel bubble to beyond this month given that the number of local unlinked cases in Hong Kong is still high, says CAAS.
The exact start date of the arrangement will be reviewed late this month.
The move comes as Hong Kong hunkers down under harsher social distancing measures in anticipation of what health authorities have warned could be the worst Covid-19 wave so far.
Hong Kong's daily new infections have crossed 70 for more than a week.
The spike was led initially by a growing dance club cluster of more than 500, most of whom are tai tais and their young dancing instructors.

Post Description:
The launch of the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble will be deferred for 2 weeks, with the new date to be announced later.
Flights for the travel bubble had been slated to start on Sunday.
Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung said on Saturday that authorities in both cities agreed that it would be better to defer it given the evolving situation in Hong Kong, after the city saw a spike in Covid-19 cases.
"We will review within two weeks on the new launch date and update again," he said in a statement on Facebook.

Post Description:
Kindergarten graduation ceremonies are a joy to look forward to at this time of the year ‚Äî seeing the enthusiasm of the graduating children and sharing in the excitement of their parents and teachers.

This year, with the pandemic, the year-end concerts and graduation ceremonies turned into hybrid events, with the children at school and attendees watching online. I joined two virtual kindergarten graduation ceremonies in my constituency this month ‚Äî My First Skool at Bedok South Blk 1 and @pcf.sg Sparkletots at Bedok Blk 30.

Despite the challenging school year, our children have adjusted well, thanks to the dedication of teachers and parents. Our little ones have been resilient and adapted to new norms, not only in their own lives but accepting changes in their parents‚Äô routines as well.

To our graduating K2 students ‚Äî congratulations! I hope you continue to enjoy your learning journey as you embark on a new adventure in primary school. Keep learning and keep growing. üéì

([1] Photo from My First Skool; [2] Photo from @pcf.sg)
Comments: Congratulations! I‚Äôm going to be a parent in December. So 4,5  years later she would do the same thing üòÅ

Post Description:
Like many of our events this year, the annual PCF Teachers‚Äô Day get together went online this year. @maliki_osman, @kiathowsg (and special guest üë∂), @chuanjin1 and I joined around 230 PCF teachers and staff from 14 centres across Bedok, Kampong Chai Chee, Siglap and Kembangan-Chai Chee for their virtual Teachers‚Äô Day Celebration on Thursday.

When schools went on full home-based learning during the circuit breaker, our teachers were resilient in the face of the disruptions and uncertainties. They continued on resolutely ‚Äî coming up with new ways to impart knowledge and adjusting and adapting as the weeks went by. My thanks to parents and family members for your support as we all jointly rediscovered the teaching and learning journey in this new context. And well done to our students for being adaptable. Perhaps the most important lesson our teachers will impart to their students this year will be the one demonstrated by their actions ‚Äî of not giving up during tough times and finding new ways to overcome challenges together.

The theme of the celebration was ‚ÄúHats off‚Äù so teachers and staff gamely showed up in their most colourful and creative headgear! Indeed, hats off to all our teachers for your dedication, for doing your best to protect and nurture our children. This Teachers‚Äô Day, let us remember to keep learning, innovating and adapting. 

Happy Teachers‚Äô Day to all our wonderful teachers and educators!
Comments: Very Good! The Teachers are important in shaping our young! A lot of Hardwork to mould a student and bring out the best in the student.

Post Description:
Happy Youth Day!‚Å£
‚Å£
I know this is a difficult time to come of age. But I am glad you are taking this in your stride.‚Å£
‚Å£
For those of you who are studying, I am glad you adjusted well to home-based learning and not seeing your friends during the circuit breaker.‚Å£
‚Å£
I have heard and read many stories of how our youth are volunteering their time to help the vulnerable among us during this period, like the four individuals featured in this @gov.sg video.‚Å£
‚Å£
Do not let the challenges you are facing deter you. You can turn anxiety into action. And you have my assurance that we will not allow a lost generation in Singapore.‚Å£
‚Å£
Stay safe and enjoy the school holiday tomorrow (for those of you who are studying)!‚Å£
‚Å£
#SingaporeTogether

‚Å£
For those of you who are studying, I am glad you adjusted well to home-based learning and not seeing your friends during the circuit breaker.‚Å£
‚Å£
I have heard and read many stories of how our youth are volunteering their time to help the vulnerable among us during this period, like the four individuals featured in this @gov.sg video.‚Å£
‚Å£
Do not let the challenges you are facing deter you. You can turn anxiety into action. And you have my assurance that we will not allow a lost generation in Singapore.‚Å£
‚Å£
Stay safe and enjoy the school holiday tomorrow (for those of you who are studying)!‚Å£
‚Å£
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Such a nice rendition and even more moving stories of SG unsung heroes

Post Description:
Like many of you, I have been concerned about how vulnerable segments of our society have coped during the circuit breaker. While the measures are necessary to keep everyone safe, it has posed additional challenges for the more vulnerable, including those with special needs.‚Å£
‚Å£
I remember a young person I met at @theartfacultysg when I visited the @enablingvillage in August last year. Catherine Tang is a salesperson at this store, which serves as a platform to promote and showcase the talent of people with autism and related challenges. She was a very persuasive salesperson, and I left the store happy with a bagful of purchases. The Autism Resource Centre had trained her well for her job.‚Å£
‚Å£
Like many of us, Catherine has been working from home during this time. She has been attending online courses to improve her customer service skills and working on The Art Faculty‚Äôs online store (www.theartfaculty.sg). ‚Å£
‚Å£
As we come to the end of the circuit breaker, I would like to thank SG Enable and our Social Service Agency partners for taking care of those with special needs and the vulnerable in our community. By providing cooked meals, essentials and respite care, they are committed to ensuring no one falls through the cracks. Thank you very much!‚Å£
‚Å£
Even as we look forward to the end of our circuit breaker, let us continue to look out for one another and strengthen our collective actions to build a caring and inclusive society for all.‚Å£
‚Å£
#SingaporeTogether‚Å£
#SGUnited‚Å£
‚Å£
(With Catherine Tang and my newly-purchased XL fans by designers Muhammad Khairul Bin Asmi and Glenn Phua during my visit in August 2019.)
Comments: Shoutout to the wonderful people and artists featured at the @enablingvillage ! Simply love the merchandise there and yes customer service by Catherine is always top notch!‚ô•Ô∏è

Post Description:
I was very happy to e-meet many familiar faces from the social service sector on Saturday, together with @desmond.lee, @gracefu.hy and @indraneerajah, ahead of my Ministerial Statement next Tuesday.

We heard from 30 social service sector partners, on the challenges they and their clients are facing. We discussed how our social service agencies can strengthen collaboration and capability building. Their passion to serve came through during the dialogue, as they are doing all they can to strengthen support for vulnerable members of our community during the circuit breaker. The circuit breaker has accelerated the shift to digital, as more services are provided online. This highlighted both the potential and also the current constraints of going digital. Many also shared their concerns about the difficulties with fundraising during this period.

Many good ideas were raised. I will look at how we can better support the social service sector as part of the upcoming Budget. We will also work with the sector to embrace digitalisation, accelerate transformation and scale up new capabilities.

What is even more heartening is how the sector is working together. Some participants were already working closely together, and new areas of collaboration were identified during our discussions. The sector faces many common challenges, but we can overcome them if we work in partnership, and put our collective effort into tackling them. This is the spirit of our #SingaporeTogether movement.

We are making good progress towards building a more caring and inclusive society. We will build an even better tomorrow, with the strong support of social service agencies.

#SGBudget2020 ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
(MCI Photos by Betty Chua)

Post Description:
Today marks the end of the fasting month of Ramadan for our Muslim friends.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Usually, Tampines residents would come together to celebrate this special occasion with bazaars, performances, and other festive activities in our community. This year, due to COVID-19, we are celebrating a homely Hari Raya.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
As we celebrate Hari Raya, we celebrate the spirit of caring, giving, and togetherness ‚Äî just like the spirit of #SGUnited and #SingaporeTogether.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
These are unprecedented and trying times for everyone. However, I am glad to see Singaporeans remain strong and resilient. Our Tampines residents have continued to help and care for those in need. Our Muslim community has also shown kindness and understanding, despite having to scale down on many of our activities during this period.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us continue to stay home and stay safe during this period, so that we can look forward to celebrating many more special occasions with our families and friends!‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri to all Muslims in Singapore.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
- - - - - - - -‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Saya bangga penduduk Melayu/Islam kita telah menunjukkan kesabaran dan berdaya tahan bersama masyarakat Singapura yang lain dalam usaha menangani penularan COVID-19 ini. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Meskipun suasana Raya tahun ini mungkin berlainan, namun ia tidak harus mematahkan semangat dan keceriaan kita menyambut bersama orang yang tersayang.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri kepada semua penduduk Islam Singapura.
Comments: üíú Blessed Eid Mubarak to my fellow Malay friends ‚ö™Ô∏è

Post Description:
I recall fondly how I had a buka puasa with the community at @wgeylangserai at this time last year, followed by a visit to the Geylang Serai Bazaar. Earlier this evening, I joined @masagosz, @maliki_osman, leaders from our Malay/Muslim organisations, and community partners for an e-Buka Puasa instead, given our circuit breaker measures.‚Å£
‚Å£
WGS and MUIS organised this ‚Äòlive‚Äô e-Buka Puasa on WGS‚Äôs Facebook Page, with chit-chat sessions and music performances.‚Å£
‚Å£
I thank all our Muslims for your understanding in making these difficult adjustments, while keeping the community spirit strong and supporting the fight against COVID-19. This care and togetherness is the very spirit of #SingaporeTogether.‚Å£
‚Å£
I hope our Muslim friends will have a good time with your families preparing to usher in Hari Raya over the next few days.‚Å£
‚Å£
- - - - - - - -‚Å£
‚Å£
Saya teringat pada tahun lalu saya berpeluang berbuka puasa di Wisma Geylang Serai (WGS) dan berkunjung ke bazar Hari Raya. Malam ini, ekoran langkah pemutus rantaian jangkitan, saya bersama Masagos Zulkifli, Dr Maliki Osman, dan para pemimpin serta rakan-rakan dari beberapa pertubuhan Melayu/Islam di Singapura mengikuti sesi e-Buka Puasa.‚Å£
‚Å£
WGS dengan kerjasama MUIS telah menganjurkan sesi e-Buka Puasa ini secara ‚Äòlive‚Äô melalui laman Facebook WGS. Sesi ‚Äòlive‚Äô ini juga padat dengan pelbagai persembahan dan sesi bersembang.‚Å£
‚Å£
Saya ingin mengucapkan terima kasih kepada rakan-rakan Muslim kita kerana membuat penyesuaian demi mengharungi cabaran COVID-19 bersama. Ini adalah semangat #SGTeguhBersatu.‚Å£
‚Å£
Semoga rakan-rakan Muslim kita ceria menyambut kedatangan Hari Raya disamping keluarga tersayang.‚Å£
‚Å£
#SGUnited
Comments: Encik Heng, ibu bapa saya kata makan di kedai Teh Tarik lebih sedap daripada kedai2 di Wisma. Awak pernah cuba?

Post Description:
We will be exiting the circuit breaker when it ends on 1 June. The number of new community cases is in the low single-digits, and our surveillance shows that the number of undetected cases in the community is small. While there are new cases in our migrant worker dormitories, the situation has stabilised.‚Å£
‚Å£
We are preparing to re-open some of our economic and social activities. But learning from the experience of other countries, this has to be done cautiously and gradually. If we re-open too quickly, we risk new waves of infection, which could be even more disruptive to lives and livelihoods. As announced by the Multi-Ministry Taskforce, we will be resuming social and economic activities in phases, with additional safeguards in place.‚Å£
‚Å£
I understand the disappointment of some businesses and workers who will not be able to resume activities immediately when the circuit breaker ends. For these workers and businesses, the Government will help tide you over this period of continued closure. I will announce the details in Parliament next Tuesday, 26 May.‚Å£
‚Å£
Medical experts have cautioned that this smart and agile virus will continue to be in our midst and in global circulation for some time to come. This is why all of us in Singapore and in the global community must not let our guard down. Some of the safe distancing measures will be here to stay. COVID-19 is changing our way of life and livelihoods. We must recognise that it is important for all of us to adjust our lifestyles and adapt our business models.‚Å£
‚Å£
I thank everyone in Singapore for your understanding and cooperation, as well as for your mutual care and concern for one other during this circuit breaker. Let‚Äôs continue to stay vigilant and civic-minded in the months ahead.‚Å£
‚Å£
#SGUnited
Comments: @hengsweekeat Sir, may I suggest to have guidelines for visiting family members from different households to wear mask, no sharing of food or utensils etc during visits to minimise transmission to our elders? For consideration plsüôè

Comments: Thank You Mr Heng and your Team for keeping Spore safe and extending help to keep jobs and businesses. Opening up of pre-schools, perhaps should be reconsidered seriously. Reasons: 1. These very young children do not have exam pressure, 2. At this young age, they cannot take care of themselves by wearing face masks properly or keeping hygienic. 3. The teachers do not have the time to look into taking care of each kid. 4. Many grand parents, parents or helpers will congregate to fetch them to and fro. 5.Those children without pte pick up need the school buses to fetch them. Usually buses need an optimum passenger load. Also frequent disinfecting of buses and school areas cannot be guaranteed. 6. Many such young children are prone to flu, cough and fever during normal times, hence covid-19 is even more critical to keep them safe from crowds.

As announced by the Multi-Ministry Taskforce, we will be resuming social and economic activities in phases, with additional safeguards in place.‚Å£
‚Å£
I understand the disappointment of some businesses and workers who will not be able to resume activities immediately when the circuit breaker ends. For these workers and businesses, the Government will help tide you over this period of continued closure. I will announce the details in Parliament next Tuesday, 26 May.‚Å£
‚Å£
Medical experts have cautioned that this smart and agile virus will continue to be in our midst and in global circulation for some time to come. This is why all of us in Singapore and in the global community must not let our guard down. Some of the safe distancing measures will be here to stay. COVID-19 is changing our way of life and livelihoods. We must recognise that it is important for all of us to adjust our lifestyles and adapt our business models.‚Å£
‚Å£
I thank everyone in Singapore for your understanding and cooperation, as well as for your mutual care and concern for one other during this circuit breaker. Let‚Äôs continue to stay vigilant and civic-minded in the months ahead.‚Å£
‚Å£
#SGUnited
Comments: And btw the companies you put into phase 3, you are most certainly going to doom many of them into bankruptcy. So pls think about that! They may have been good companies and the hard work of people. It may not be your lost but many others people‚Äôs lost of their livelihoods. Consider before you make such rules. There are only 1-2 local cases and don‚Äôt destroy people‚Äôs lives for poor advise and thought process.

Post Description:
For many Tampines residents and myself, a visit to @ourtampineshub used to be a weekly (or even more frequent) affair. I used to go there for events and would often meet many residents shopping, exercising, finding good makan, attending classes, visiting the library, enjoying movie screenings, and so much more ‚Äî there‚Äôs always something going on at OTH.

OTH is a lot quieter these days ‚Äî and for good reason, as many residents and Singaporeans understand the need and importance of staying home during this period.

The OTH team has worked hard to move the buzz online ‚Äî with OTH‚Äôs Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube channels offering contests, workouts, craft tutorials, and concerts to keep everyone staying safe at home entertained and occupied. So you can check out OTH virtually!

I know many residents are looking forward to visiting OTH again. As we slowly and gradually emerge from the circuit breaker, it will not be the same as before. We will have to observe precautionary measures including SafeEntry, to protect the community and prevent a surge of new cases. In the meantime, let us #stayhomeforSG, look out for our neighbours, and make Tampines a safe home for all.

OTH ‚Äî till we meet again, soon.

#TampinesTogether
#SGUnited
Comments: One of the shop say we no need to apply they will put the money to our bank is in true

Post Description:
It‚Äôs the second week of the school holidays. I hope our kids (and parents) are making the best use of your #stayhome in a meaningful way.

You can check out @alistsg ‚Äî from online arts and cultural concerts, virtual museum tours to hands-on arts and crafts, there is something for everyone, for the young and the young at heart.

Librarians from @publiclibrarysg are also holding storytelling sessions for young children in the four different languages on their Facebook Page so that the kids can continue to cultivate the habit of reading even when the libraries are closed. Or expend that excess energy with home workout ideas and healthy habits with the @hpbsg. You can also discover more ideas from the @moesingapore's Parent Kits (https://www.moe.gov.sg/parentkit) on how to care for your child‚Äôs well-being and adjust in this new normal.

Students who are taking their national exams will be returning to school next week to start their preparations. Whether at home or at school, I hope you continue to make good use of your time to stay curious, while building stronger bonds with your loved ones and friends.

#stayhomeforSG ‚†Ä
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Sorry can we ask is on the june 1 all the children can go back to school

Post Description:
Families will be marking a #stayhome #MothersDay this year. Some of you may not be able to be with your mother physically, due to the circuit breaker. Still, we can make it as meaningful, by gathering our families together on the telephone or video to show our love for our mums, in appreciation for their hard work and sacrifices.

You can also join @desmond.lee on @familiesforlife‚Äôs Facebook page ‚Äî with a special online Mothers‚Äô Day celebration concert and you can sing your heart out for all the mummies out there.

Happy Mother‚Äôs Day to all!
Comments: Many Thanks Mr Heng Blessings to you and your family

Post Description:
Today is the last day of full Home-Based Learning (HBL). The past four weeks have been challenging for everyone involved.

For Teachers, this means putting in extra time and effort to prepare. HBL is a different mode of teaching, and you have to be creative and learn new skills to make online learning as engaging as possible.

For Parents, you have to support your children in the best possible way, even as you juggle working from home and housework.

For Students, I know many of you miss your classmates, your favourite hangouts and CCAs in schools. E-learning is not new, but having to do so remotely for a month is a completely different way to learn.

Challenging as it is for everyone, this experience also creates many memorable stories. I urge you all to share these, so that we can all learn about what worked, what did not; why not, and how we can do better.

Let us all be prepared to try new things, adapt and grow with this new experience, and we may just become more innovative after this! The first step in any innovation is to overcome the fear of the unknown. But if the new approach is better, we can learn better. If the traditional approach is better, we will appreciate it more, and look forward to going back to school!

Education Minister @ongyekung has brought forward our mid-year school holidays, so that everyone can have a respite. I strongly encourage all parents and students to explore new activities to spend quality time together, at home. I hope all our teachers who have been working very hard can also take a well-deserved break, before some of you have to help graduating cohorts prepare for their national exams from 19 May.

The second half of the circuit breaker is just as crucial. Stay strong and stay safe, as we #StayhomeforSG.

#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Thanks to the teachers and school for continuing the students learning at home during the pandemic. They put in lots of efforts and passion in their works.

The second half of the circuit breaker is just as crucial. Stay strong and stay safe, as we #StayhomeforSG.

#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Yes sir @hengsweekeat . Been juggling between housework, HBL, and taking care of other little one at home is very challenging since my work was suspended! üòÖ But we made it! So lets continue to stay safe everyone. Take care! We can do it Singapore!

Post Description:
Today is the last day of full Home-Based Learning (HBL). The past four weeks have been challenging for everyone involved.

For Teachers, this means putting in extra time and effort to prepare. HBL is a different mode of teaching, and you have to be creative and learn new skills to make online learning as engaging as possible.

For Parents, you have to support your children in the best possible way, even as you juggle working from home and housework.

For Students, I know many of you miss your classmates, your favourite hangouts and CCAs in schools. E-learning is not new, but having to do so remotely for a month is a completely different way to learn.

Challenging as it is for everyone, this experience also creates many memorable stories. I urge you all to share these, so that we can all learn about what worked, what did not; why not, and how we can do better.

Let us all be prepared to try new things, adapt and grow with this new experience, and we may just become more innovative after this! The first step in any innovation is to overcome the fear of the unknown. But if the new approach is better, we can learn better. If the traditional approach is better, we will appreciate it more, and look forward to going back to school!

Education Minister @ongyekung has brought forward our mid-year school holidays, so that everyone can have a respite. I strongly encourage all parents and students to explore new activities to spend quality time together, at home. I hope all our teachers who have been working very hard can also take a well-deserved break, before some of you have to help graduating cohorts prepare for their national exams from 19 May.

The second half of the circuit breaker is just as crucial. Stay strong and stay safe, as we #StayhomeforSG.

#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether
Comments: Check ALL student's eyesight. We have too many young myopic kids already.

Post Description:
The months of April and May will be a test of our resilience, as individuals and as a society.

The number of new cases has risen sharply, due largely to the clusters in our migrant worker dormitories. There are signs that our measures are working in the wider community, but the numbers ‚Äî especially unlinked cases ‚Äî have not come down enough.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This is why PM @leehsienloong has just announced a further tightening of measures for two weeks, and an extension of the circuit breaker by four weeks, until 1 Jun.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The decision to extend the circuit breaker is important in our fight against COVID-19. But the difficult global situation coupled with our extension, will put greater stress on our businesses and workers.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
To all our companies and our workers, we are with you in these difficult times. We will extend key support measures in the Solidarity Budget into the month of May.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will extend the 75% wage subsidy under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) to all sectors for the month of May. I urge employers to treat their workers fairly, and to do their best to retain them, and make full use of the support measures for training and corporate upgrading.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will further enhance the JSS to include shareholder-directors who did not qualify for JSS, based on the earlier criteria, and also did not qualify for SIRS.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Ä¢ I will also be waiving the Foreign Worker Levy (FWL) due in May and provide employers with another $750 in FWL rebate for every foreign worker in employment.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Families who need help because their breadwinners have lost their jobs can apply for the COVID-19 Support Grant from 1 May 2020.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
More details can be found on the MOF website (www.mof.gov.sg).
‚†Ä
The extension of the Solidarity Budget will amount to $3.8 billion. But the financial support works only if we each do our part and help one another out.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The coming weeks will be even more critical, as we batten down our hatches. We cannot be certain when this crisis will pass. But you can be assured that we will be here with you, for you. As long as we stand in solidarity with one another, we can rough out the waves better and emerge stronger.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
#SGBudget2020‚†Ä
#StayhomeforSG‚†Ä
#SGUnited

Families who need help because their breadwinners have lost their jobs can apply for the COVID-19 Support Grant from 1 May 2020.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
More details can be found on the MOF website (www.mof.gov.sg).
‚†Ä
The extension of the Solidarity Budget will amount to $3.8 billion. But the financial support works only if we each do our part and help one another out.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The coming weeks will be even more critical, as we batten down our hatches. We cannot be certain when this crisis will pass. But you can be assured that we will be here with you, for you. As long as we stand in solidarity with one another, we can rough out the waves better and emerge stronger.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
#SGBudget2020‚†Ä
#StayhomeforSG‚†Ä
#SGUnited
Comments: Dear Mr Heng, appreciated the supports that govt is giving to all business and household personnel. However, I would like to clarify, besides the latest enhanced JSS packaged, is there any possible way that Companies can apply for any other grant that can help with company to tide over during this period. As Company does not have income since the CB and has to pay for regular salary and huge expenses (dormitory rental, utilities, licensing fees, etc). Looking for your favourable replies. Thank you.

Post Description:
Today is Good Friday and the start of the Easter weekend.

For Christians, today is a time of reflection. This year, even more so.

Churches in Singapore are physically closed as part of the ‚Äúcircuit breaker‚Äù. So are churches in many parts of the world, where cities are in lock-down. Many are holding their Good Friday and Easter services online.

I hope it is no less meaningful an Easter weekend ‚Äî with more time for solitude, greater bonding with your family, and keeping in touch with your friends through technology.

I wish all Christians a blessed Easter weekend. (MCI Photo by Betty Chua)

Post Description:
#StayhomeforSG challenge was launched yesterday to encourage Singaporeans to stay active and engaged, even as we stay home. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Like many of us, I am concerned about how our seniors are coping, that they may feel lonely or isolated. Our elderly are most vulnerable to COVID-19. With the circuit breaker in place, they should stay home as much as possible. We can visit to assist them with their daily needs while keeping the visits short. This is the best way to protect their well-being. It is not easy to explain that we may sometimes have to stay away because we care, but we must do so.

We can still show care and concern for the elderly, even when we are not physically present. There are many ways to keep in touch ‚Äî through WhatsApp, video-conferencing apps such as Skype, or just a simple phone call.

We also have much more content on TV during this period. For those who are interested in getai, you can also tune into e-getais every Monday and Thursday on Lex S Watch Live Channel's FB page. This is a @gov.sg collaboration with producer @jackneock for our seniors to enjoy the familiar tunes from yesterdays in the comfort of our homes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

Comments: I pray for the well being of our seniors. They have given so much to Singapore

Post Description:
#StayhomeforSG challenge was launched yesterday to encourage Singaporeans to stay active and engaged, even as we stay home. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Like many of us, I am concerned about how our seniors are coping, that they may feel lonely or isolated. Our elderly are most vulnerable to COVID-19. With the circuit breaker in place, they should stay home as much as possible. We can visit to assist them with their daily needs while keeping the visits short. This is the best way to protect their well-being. It is not easy to explain that we may sometimes have to stay away because we care, but we must do so.

We can still show care and concern for the elderly, even when we are not physically present. There are many ways to keep in touch ‚Äî through WhatsApp, video-conferencing apps such as Skype, or just a simple phone call.

We also have much more content on TV during this period. For those who are interested in getai, you can also tune into e-getais every Monday and Thursday on Lex S Watch Live Channel's FB page. This is a @gov.sg collaboration with producer @jackneock for our seniors to enjoy the familiar tunes from yesterdays in the comfort of our homes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

#SingaporeTogether‚†Ä
#SGUnited‚†Ä
‚†Ä
(At a Ministerial Community Walkabout at Geylang Serai in November 2019. / MCI Photo by Rebecca Yang)
Comments: Mr Heng, my questions: 1. What if the whole family stayd together? Does this mean that in order to protect the grandparents, the younger family members should move out? 2. What if the grand parents are not old and fragilecas assumed but lead an active and healthy life and are relatively young and have been looking after the grand children while the parents are working? 3.  If the healthy grandparents actually stay next door or across the block like 3 mins walk,the grand kids are also not allowed to be with the grand parents? 4. If childcare centres are so safe, why do the pre-schools, all schools need to close? Mr Heng, it is good to apply CB but in this case, I think some form of flexibility should be allowed. Reason is now most parents have to work from home and very young kids are a big distraction. They affect the parents work negatively. Also assuming that all grandparents are old, frail and unhealthy is not altogether correct. Hope that certain form of flexibility be allowed. Who can be approached in MOH or govt officers when the appeal has to be carried out?

#SingaporeTogether‚†Ä
#SGUnited‚†Ä
‚†Ä
(At a Ministerial Community Walkabout at Geylang Serai in November 2019. / MCI Photo by Rebecca Yang)
Comments: Stay safe wear a mask on to show a example to the elderly people .that is the way to win more votes for the coming general election

Post Description:
#StayhomeforSG challenge was launched yesterday to encourage Singaporeans to stay active and engaged, even as we stay home. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Like many of us, I am concerned about how our seniors are coping, that they may feel lonely or isolated. Our elderly are most vulnerable to COVID-19. With the circuit breaker in place, they should stay home as much as possible. We can visit to assist them with their daily needs while keeping the visits short. This is the best way to protect their well-being. It is not easy to explain that we may sometimes have to stay away because we care, but we must do so.

We can still show care and concern for the elderly, even when we are not physically present. There are many ways to keep in touch ‚Äî through WhatsApp, video-conferencing apps such as Skype, or just a simple phone call.

We also have much more content on TV during this period. For those who are interested in getai, you can also tune into e-getais every Monday and Thursday on Lex S Watch Live Channel's FB page. This is a @gov.sg collaboration with producer @jackneock for our seniors to enjoy the familiar tunes from yesterdays in the comfort of our homes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

Post Description:
#StayhomeforSG challenge was launched yesterday to encourage Singaporeans to stay active and engaged, even as we stay home. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Like many of us, I am concerned about how our seniors are coping, that they may feel lonely or isolated. Our elderly are most vulnerable to COVID-19. With the circuit breaker in place, they should stay home as much as possible. We can visit to assist them with their daily needs while keeping the visits short. This is the best way to protect their well-being. It is not easy to explain that we may sometimes have to stay away because we care, but we must do so.

We can still show care and concern for the elderly, even when we are not physically present. There are many ways to keep in touch ‚Äî through WhatsApp, video-conferencing apps such as Skype, or just a simple phone call.

We also have much more content on TV during this period. For those who are interested in getai, you can also tune into e-getais every Monday and Thursday on Lex S Watch Live Channel's FB page. This is a @gov.sg collaboration with producer @jackneock for our seniors to enjoy the familiar tunes from yesterdays in the comfort of our homes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Let us all help our elderly family members adapt so that they can remain happy and engaged at home. Safe distancing does not mean social isolation.‚†Ä ‚†Ä
I encourage those with good ideas on how to keep our seniors engaged at home to come forward and take part in the #StayhomeforSG challenge.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Together, we can get through this difficult period.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

Post Description:
We are living in extraordinary times.

This is the first time in our history that we will be closing all schools and most workplaces across the island for a month ‚Äî a painful but necessary ‚Äòcircuit breaker‚Äô to stem the tide of COVID-19 cases.

Tomorrow afternoon, when Parliament sits, I will announce additional support for workers, businesses and households, to help tide them through this period.

The COVID-19 situation has taken a very sharp turn, both globally and locally. Strong measures have to be taken to protect lives, but the economy has taken a hit as a result. Tomorrow will mark the third round of support measures in less than two months ‚Äî coming after the Unity Budget on 18 Feb and the Resilience Budget on 26 March. This too is another first.

We must remain steadfast in the face of crisis, and stand in solidarity with one another during these difficult times. I am therefore naming this set of measures to tide us through the 'circuit breaker' the Solidarity Budget.

Unity, Resilience, Solidarity ‚Äî these values will come to define who we are as a people. The bonds that bind us together will be forged and renewed in this crisis, much as how the turbulent years of Independence brought our founding generation together. As we battle on, we are most grateful that earlier generations have saved up and built strong foundations for us. These strengths have given us the wherewithal to protect our people and their jobs.

This is a defining chapter of our generation. Together, we will pull through and emerge stronger. When the storm eventually subsides, as all storms do, I am confident that as a stronger society, we can build an even better future for our children and our grandchildren.

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Clement)
Comments: Thank alot sir ..We are prepared on COVID19 crisis.

I waited three days to buy a bag of rice only to turn around every time, I see a Long line at the supermarkets (to not risk being in crowded spaces with or without masks). Also half these people have already bought their share of rice.
