We must remain steadfast in the face of crisis, and stand in solidarity with one another during these difficult times. I am therefore naming this set of measures to tide us through the 'circuit breaker' the Solidarity Budget.

Unity, Resilience, Solidarity ‚Äî these values will come to define who we are as a people. The bonds that bind us together will be forged and renewed in this crisis, much as how the turbulent years of Independence brought our founding generation together. As we battle on, we are most grateful that earlier generations have saved up and built strong foundations for us. These strengths have given us the wherewithal to protect our people and their jobs.

This is a defining chapter of our generation. Together, we will pull through and emerge stronger. When the storm eventually subsides, as all storms do, I am confident that as a stronger society, we can build an even better future for our children and our grandchildren.

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Clement)
Comments: Thank you DPM. All this shall passed soon. ‚ù§Ô∏è @hengsweekeat

Post Description:
We are living in extraordinary times.

This is the first time in our history that we will be closing all schools and most workplaces across the island for a month ‚Äî a painful but necessary ‚Äòcircuit breaker‚Äô to stem the tide of COVID-19 cases.

Tomorrow afternoon, when Parliament sits, I will announce additional support for workers, businesses and households, to help tide them through this period.

The COVID-19 situation has taken a very sharp turn, both globally and locally. Strong measures have to be taken to protect lives, but the economy has taken a hit as a result. Tomorrow will mark the third round of support measures in less than two months ‚Äî coming after the Unity Budget on 18 Feb and the Resilience Budget on 26 March. This too is another first.

We must remain steadfast in the face of crisis, and stand in solidarity with one another during these difficult times. I am therefore naming this set of measures to tide us through the 'circuit breaker' the Solidarity Budget.

Unity, Resilience, Solidarity ‚Äî these values will come to define who we are as a people. The bonds that bind us together will be forged and renewed in this crisis, much as how the turbulent years of Independence brought our founding generation together. As we battle on, we are most grateful that earlier generations have saved up and built strong foundations for us. These strengths have given us the wherewithal to protect our people and their jobs.

This is a defining chapter of our generation. Together, we will pull through and emerge stronger. When the storm eventually subsides, as all storms do, I am confident that as a stronger society, we can build an even better future for our children and our grandchildren.

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Clement)
Comments: üëçüëçüëçwell done, DPM! SGUnited to emerge stronger and more sustainable for many generations to come!

Post Description:
The circuit breaker measures that we have put in are to protect our people. But these disrupt our normal routine. I am glad that many of our public service officers and volunteers have been going around to see how people are coping.

Our people in Singapore have been very responsible ‚Äî they are staying calm and helping one another.

In Tampines, more residents are doing their Saturday grocery shopping, with some buying more than usual.

Island-wide, staff in our shops and supermarkets have been working really hard to replenish stocks on the shelves as fast as they can. Supermarkets and wet markets will remain open. You can still get your favourite food ‚Äî all food establishments may also remain open for delivery or ‚Äòta pao‚Äô during this month-long period where we come together to fight the spread of COVID-19.

I trust that our people will continue to be patient and understanding towards the hardworking staff ‚Äî in our supermarkets, F&B outlets and other essential services.

Let‚Äôs continue to look out for one another ‚Äî and stay united to overcome this crisis. 
#SGUnited
Comments: This 1 month' period is good to see the effectiveness of encouraging social distancing. Applause this initiatives by the govt to curb Covid19.  It's not difficult to get over since our daily food establishments are open.

Post Description:
PM @leehsienloong announced yesterday a set of significantly stricter measures, as a circuit breaker to curb the escalating number of new COVID-19 cases. Most workplaces, except for essential services and key economic sectors, will close for one month from next Tuesday.

We are implementing these painful but necessary measures to protect lives. The stronger the measures we adopt, the bigger the disruption and costs on businesses. We remain equally committed to protecting jobs and livelihoods during this time. Many businesses are looking at your cash flow and working out alternative arrangements over the weekend. I understand your worries.

That is why I am working with my team at the @mof_sg, together with other government agencies, to further increase support for businesses during the period of the circuit breaker. This includes boosting the Job Support Scheme and waiving the foreign worker levy for the month of April, so that companies can retain and pay their workers. We will also be passing legislation on Tuesday (7 April) in Parliament to ensure that property tax rebates are passed through to tenants.

This is undoubtedly a difficult month for many businesses. Additional help is on the way. I hope that businesses can tide through this month, hold on to your workers, and resume activities once the circuit breaker is lifted. Together, we can pull through this crisis.

I will announce the details in my ministerial statement in Parliament on Monday.

#SGUnited (Taken during my recent visit to Changi Airport Terminal 3 on 30 March 2020./ MCI Photo by LH Goh)
Comments: Thanks for time and effort done by you and your team Mr DPM, do take care and rest well.

I will announce the details in my ministerial statement in Parliament on Monday.

#SGUnited (Taken during my recent visit to Changi Airport Terminal 3 on 30 March 2020./ MCI Photo by LH Goh)

Post Description:
Last Friday, we announced the closure of all mosques in Singapore for five days, to facilitate cleaning and disinfection procedures so as to prevent the emergence of new clusters. This move came after two Singaporeans who attended a religious gathering in Malaysia had returned here with COVID-19. As of today, a total of five Singaporeans who attended the event have now tested positive for the virus. They had visited 10 mosques in Singapore during their infectious period. Today, @masagosz announced that the mosque closure will be extended till 26 March 2020 to further limit the spread of the virus.

I understand that the closure of mosques and suspension of Friday prayers will cause inconvenience to our friends from the Muslim community. But this is a necessary move in order to reduce the risk of secondary transmission and to protect all Singaporeans. In a mosque setting, it is challenging to conduct contact tracing due to the lack of registration for regular congregants. Upon the reopening of mosques, additional precautionary measures will be implemented to reduce the risk of spread of the virus.

Located in Tampines Central, @darulghufran is Singapore‚Äôs largest mosque and caters to around 5,500 congregants. I very much appreciate that our Muslim community understands the need to take these precautionary measures. I thank you all for your support. Let us continue to look out for one another during this critical period.

#SGUnited (Disinfection at Masjid Ghufran which took place today.)
Comments: It pains us but we understand and support the precautionary measures. Let‚Äôs work together and overcome this. üí™üèºüíï

Post Description:
A message from @ongyekung to our friends in Hong Kong!
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
The Singapore-Hong Kong Air Travel Bubble takes off next Sunday, 22 November, with the start of daily ‚Äòbubble‚Äô flights between our two cities.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Officials from both sides have worked hard to put in place measures to allow air travel to resume safely. Travellers will have to get used to new regulations and COVID-19 swab tests ‚Äì all part and parcel of the new normal.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
We are proceeding cautiously, but if the arrangement is successful and the pandemic continues to stay under control on both sides, we can look forward to expanding the bubble to more flights, and hopefully, to more destinations as well. ‚Äì LHL‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Comments: Singapore got nothing to see

Post Description:
Term 3 of the school year started today. For many students, it was the first time back in school after almost two months ‚Äî students did Home Based Learning when the circuit breaker began in April, and had their mid-year school holidays in May. I‚Äôm sure many of you were excited to see friends and teachers again!
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
HBL had become the ‚Äònew normal‚Äô during the circuit breaker. Today as we start Phase 1 of our safe opening, there will be yet another ‚Äònew normal‚Äô. Students and teachers returned to a different environment than when they were last in school.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Parents will understandably be anxious for their children. Rest assured that @moesingapore has taken comprehensive measures to keep students, teachers, and staff safe. We will take time to get used to the precautions, but they are necessary to protect everyone. Meanwhile, we are watching the situation closely, and will do everything necessary to gradually resume our normal activities while keeping teachers and students safe. ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(Xingnan Primary School students queueing up to wash their hands in their classroom. / MOE Photo)‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Comments: This is amazing news and while we are still fighting for the BLM movement and sending support to our American friends, let us not forget about the more subtle racism which also exists in our society. Change is needed and it is only possible if we are all in it

Post Description:
Tomorrow, we will be lifting some circuit breaker measures. A big relief to all, but certainly not without its risks.

The number of daily cases in the community has come down considerably. More patients have now recovered and been discharged, than are still receiving care. But COVID-19 is far from defeated.

I know many of you are looking forward to seeing your friends in school again, or visiting parents and grandparents. But we must remain cautious and vigilant.

Please keep your guard up. Maintain safe distancing, wear masks when outdoors and at work, watch your personal hygiene and wash hands frequently. Avoid crowds and gatherings. If we all do this, then life can go on more or less normally after the circuit breaker. We don‚Äôt want COVID-19 cases to spike up again, and be forced to tighten up once more.

Dealing with COVID-19 is a marathon, not a sprint. Even after a vaccine is found, everything will not simply go back to the way it was before. COVID-19 has exposed how vulnerable our way of life is. But it has also given us the opportunity to prove our mettle, and come back stronger.

As we end this circuit breaker, I thank everyone again for playing your part, so that we can now reopen safely. We must all keep at it together. Do not allow the sacrifices of our healthcare workers and others who have kept Singapore running to be in vain. ‚Äì LHL

#SGUnited (MCI Photo by Terence Tan)
Comments: Thanks PM Lee. I hope you are reading or it eventually gets to you. Hope the safe distancing measures which we have invested so much resources, such as funds and manpower will not be wasted by being lax in our efforts when it concerns public transportation for the sake of convenience. Thanks

Post Description:
Held a virtual summit with New Zealand PM @jacindaardern today. Since our last call nearly two months ago, our countries have moved from strict circuit breaking measures to a gradual, careful easing of restrictions. We talked about technological solutions and shared our strategies, including possible collaboration on vaccine development.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I was pleased to mark the one-year anniversary of the Singapore-New Zealand Enhanced Partnership, and look forward to expanding our cooperation with new initiatives that both sides value. During the global pandemic, we have spoken up against protectionism and for keeping supply chains intact. Earlier in April, we received 20 tonnes of New Zealand‚Äôs fine produce, while New Zealand received medical supplies on the return journey.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
The times are challenging, but we are dealing with the problems one by one, and planning ahead. As part of safe reopening, we are discussing creating a green lane for short-term essential travel between our countries. I hope this works out, and it will not be long before PM Ardern and I can meet in person again. ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(MCI Photo by Zinkie Aw)
Comments: Thank you so much for your hard work. Please take good care of your health.

Post Description:
It‚Äôs been more than a month since we began our circuit breaker and our city looks very different these days. This @straits_times drone video gives an intriguing view of a city on pause ‚Äî the streets and neighbourhoods look familiar and yet not.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
This circuit breaker has been tough on everyone, but I‚Äôm glad most have heeded the rules and stayed home. Thanks to our collective efforts and responsibility, community infections have come down sharply. Let‚Äôs keep it up! ‚Äì LHL

Post Description:
The mid-year school holidays start today. @moesingapore decided to bring this forward by a month, to give a break to teachers, parents, students and family members who have had to adjust to home-based learning during the circuit breaker period.

You may not be able to head outside yet, but I hope families will use this time to bond over activities at home. MOE is posting a stay-home activity idea on their Facebook Page every day. Our @nationallibrarysg librarians are holding weekday storytelling sessions for young children in the four languages on their @publiclibrarysg Facebook Page.

Some students taking their national exams this year will be returning to school on 19 May. But for the rest, as and when schools can safely reopen, I am sure everyone is looking forward to seeing their classmates and teachers in person again. ‚Äì LHL

#sgunited
Comments: Appreciate all the great efforts for üá∏üá¨ !

Some students taking their national exams this year will be returning to school on 19 May. But for the rest, as and when schools can safely reopen, I am sure everyone is looking forward to seeing their classmates and teachers in person again. ‚Äì LHL

#sgunited
Comments: Thank you PM for explaining the rationale for earlier school break. Take care

Post Description:
Tomorrow marks the start of the holy month of Ramadan, the fasting month for Muslims.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Fasting month this year will be markedly different. There will be no communal Terawih prayers, because mosques are all closed. Many would also be unable to break fast with their close family and friends, as they usually do. I hope you understand why the circuit breaker restrictions are being extended, to stamp out new COVID-19 transmissions and protect all of us.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I am glad that MUIS is providing many online resources, such as SalamSG TV to help foster the Ramadan spirit.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
To all our Muslim friends, I wish you a blessed and fulfilling fasting month. May this Ramadan be a time of quiet reflection and prayer, together with your immediate families. ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(The majestic Sultan Mosque and the quiet Arab Street area during the circuit breaker period. / MCI Photo by Fyrol)‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Comments: Happy Ramadhan to all my friends & family in Singapore! I‚Äôm still in home lockdown here in KL, hope to be back real soon. üôèüèªüôèüèª Gd luck everybody

Post Description:
It is two weeks since our COVID-19 circuit breaker started. I thank you all for complying with the restrictions. While community cases have fallen, we still need to bring their number down decisively. We also want to make sure that if any cases leak from the migrant worker population into the wider community, we can detect and contain them.

That is why we are tightening the circuit breaker measures, e.g. thinning out crowds at hot spots like wet markets, and closing more workplace premises, till 4 May. We will also extend the circuit breaker itself to 1 June.

I know that this has not been an easy time. The circuit breaker is working, but we need to do a little bit more, and for a bit longer. Let us all do our part to beat the virus, break the chain of transmission, and overcome this together.

You can watch my speech on my Facebook Page (www.facebook.com/leehsienloong) or on the PMO YouTube channel (click on the link in my profile). ‚Äì LHL 
#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether

MCI Photo by Fyrol)
Comments: üôåüôå We can get through this

Post Description:
We are now two weeks into our circuit breaker. I will be giving an update on where we are now and what we need to do next at 5pm today on TV and radio. You can also watch it ‚Äòlive‚Äô on my Facebook page (www.facebook.com/leehsienloong).‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This is an uncertain and worrying time for many of us, especially with the large number of cases in the migrant worker dorms. Our teams have been working hard to contain the spread of COVID-19 in the dorms, and look after the well-being of our migrant workers.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
I urge everyone to persevere with the circuit breaker measures, and continue to help one another through this outbreak. ‚Äì LHL‚†Ä
‚†Ä
#SGUnited‚†Ä
#SingaporeTogether‚†Ä
‚†Ä
(MCI Photo by Fyrol)

Post Description:
Today is Good Friday, a day of fasting, prayer, and penance as Christians reflect on the crucifixion and death of Jesus Christ. This spirit of solemnity continues as Christians await the resurrection on Easter Sunday.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
It has been a difficult time for people of faith, including Christians here and elsewhere in the world. They have been unable to hold their usual services because of COVID-19 measures. However, these measures are essential to protect all of us, Christians and non-Christians alike. I am heartened that most Churches have introduced online services, and hope many will continue to find solace in prayer, and be united in spirit.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I wish all Christians a blessed and healthy Easter weekend, and that you will find joy in your hearts amid the simple celebrations. ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(MCI photo by Betty Chua)
Comments: Stayed at home & had our passover feast

Post Description:
Prime Minister @jacindaardern and I spoke on the phone this afternoon. We updated each other on how we are managing COVID-19 in Singapore and New Zealand. We are both implementing strict circuit breaking measures, to break transmission of the virus and squeeze the cases down.

PM Ardern shared that after New Zealand implemented their measures, numbers only started to come down on Day 11. We are only in Day 3 and still have a long way to go. If we all comply strictly, as the New Zealanders have done, hopefully by our Day 11 we too will see positive results.

PM Ardern and I also discussed how we can support each other during this time, including keeping supply chains intact between the two countries. Both Singapore and New Zealand will continue to do our part in this global fight against COVID-19.

At home, @masagosz has announced that enforcement officers will now immediately take down the particulars of anyone breaching the measures. More details on his Facebook post today. We cannot wait to save lives. Please do your part today. ‚Äì LHL

#SGUnited (Meeting PM Jacinda Ardern during her official visit to Singapore last year. / MCI Photo by Kenji Soon)
Comments: üëè lets not waste the 5billion for this circuit breaker. Stay at home please

Post Description:
The full suite of ‚Äúcircuit breaker‚Äù measures kicked in today. Cabinet still had to meet, but we separated into two locations, connected via teleconferencing. We also spaced out to maintain safe distancing, and wore masks to keep our droplets to ourselves.

The ‚Äúcircuit breaker‚Äù is essential to fight the COVID-19 outbreak. As we expected, daily numbers of new cases are still going up, and faster than before. We must bring the numbers down, and the only way is for all of us to observe the circuit breaker measures strictly.

Stay at home, except when you have to go out to do essential work or buy food. If you need to go to the market, stagger your timing too. Avoid being part of the crowd. This is not a month long holiday, when we can go out for jalan jalan or to meet up with friends.

The health of us all depends on the actions of each of us. Please do your part. ‚Äì LHL

#SGUnited (Half the meeting group, as viewed on the TV monitor. / MCI Photo by Zinkie Aw)
Comments: Please SG the rich help me with social protection, i.e for us as pension fir not hunger die, further more in this covid19 attack. In this elderly we accidentally to be poor due to no more income, will everythings is with payment fully. Plase be kind to help your neighbor country people.

Post Description:
Today is World Health Day ‚Äì a global health campaign organised by the @who. This year‚Äôs theme celebrates the work of nurses and midwives ‚Äî a fitting one to salute the healthcare professionals working selflessly and tirelessly to care for patients in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic. My deepest thanks to all of you for your dedication and commitment to save lives and bring comfort to the ill and infirm.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Our month long circuit breaker starts today. Let us all do our part to support our healthcare professionals by staying at home, and complying with the enhanced measures in place. ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
#SGUnited
#SingaporeTogether

Post Description:
Since COVID-19, we have responded to the crisis calmly and systematically, planning ahead and adjusting our measures as the situation changed. The current situation is under control, but we want to take a few more steps now.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
I gave my third televised update today on the current situation. You can watch it on my Facebook Page (www.facebook.com/leehsienloong) or on the PMO YouTube channel (click on the link in my profile).
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Let me reassure Singaporeans that our food supply is secure and adequate. Buy just what you need, and share any extra you have with those who need it. Let‚Äôs stay calm and united during this challenging period. ‚Äì LHL

Post Description:
We have faced the novel coronavirus situation for about two weeks now.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
People are understandably anxious and fearful. But fear can end up doing more harm than the virus itself! It can lead to irrational panic, causing us to hoard facemasks or food.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Singapore has ample supplies ‚Äî already, supermarkets across Singapore have restocked. There is no need to stock up on instant noodles or toilet paper, as was widely seen on social media yesterday.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Instead, let us stay united and resolute in this outbreak. Keep helping one another, as many of you have stepped up to do. And most importantly, stay calm and carry on with our lives.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
You can watch my message on the PMO YouTube channel (click on the link in my profile). ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(MCI Photo by Betty Chua)
Comments: sir, we hear you. thank u.

People are understandably anxious and fearful. But fear can end up doing more harm than the virus itself! It can lead to irrational panic, causing us to hoard facemasks or food.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Singapore has ample supplies ‚Äî already, supermarkets across Singapore have restocked. There is no need to stock up on instant noodles or toilet paper, as was widely seen on social media yesterday.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
Instead, let us stay united and resolute in this outbreak. Keep helping one another, as many of you have stepped up to do. And most importantly, stay calm and carry on with our lives.
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
You can watch my message on the PMO YouTube channel (click on the link in my profile). ‚Äì LHL
‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä
(MCI Photo by Betty Chua)
Comments: I‚Äôm engaging in this because this is how I saw people post giving and I decided to give a try and luckily it went well, I made $10,000 just within one week all thanks to @erin_arison

Post Description:
Wishing all our Muslim friends Selamat Hari Raya Aidilfitri! 
It is a different celebration this year, as we are still in circuit breaker period. 
During the e-buka puasa events I attended, residents told me that they would still celebrate by attending online prayers and visiting family members online. Some even planned to dressed up as a family. But come 2 Jun, they will pay visits, in pairs, to their parents and grandparents. 
Everyone is making sacrifices and adjusting to the situation. Most important is to know that we are all in this together.
Comments: Selamat hari raya, maaf zahir dan batin to all Singaporean with love ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

Post Description:
The Government has just announced some initial steps to allow activities such as barbers, home-based business and laundromats to resume during the circuit breaker period in May. 
For MOE, we will enter the four-week mid-year school holidays in May. The first two weeks will be protected time for teachers. This is something we always do, to allow teachers some time to rest and recharge, although we know many of them use the time to plan lessons and stay in touch with students. 
As for the following two weeks, √¢‚Ç¨¬™starting 19 May√¢‚Ç¨¬¨, schools will bring back students from graduating cohorts, i.e. Pri 6, Sec 4 and 5, JC2 and Pre-U 3.  We know that these students have been anxious about the preparation for their national exams, and that home-based learning cannot fully substitute face to face coaching and lessons. 
Their return to school will be done in a careful and calibrated manner, with ample safe distancing. They will come back in small groups, on selected days in a week, throughout the day, and will be spaced out within the school compound. They will meet teachers one-to-one, or in small groups.  Masks are compulsory. 
We will give priority to students requiring school facilities for coursework and practical sessions, as well as those who need additional support and remediation. 
Throughout the holidays, schools will also continue to engage students with greater needs and provide care for those whose parents work in essential services and are unable to secure alternative care arrangements.  For teachers rostered during this period, they will be given protected rest time in the later half of May. 
#StayHomeStaySafeStayCurious
Comments: The right move with careful thinking, planing and execution.üëç

Post Description:
The Government has announced tighter measures during the circuit breaker period and extended it √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 4 May 2020 to 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨.
This will have implications on education. Do we extend HBL by another four weeks?
Our teachers, students and parents have been working hard to make HBL work. It hasn√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t been easy. The learning curve is steep for everyone. I thank everyone for your hard work, perseverance, patience and positivity. 
HBL is a fall back when schools are suspended; it cannot be a prolonged substitute for school. It is better to let everyone have a break from this intense period. 
MOE will therefore bring forward the June holidays to start √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 5 May until 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. By √¢‚Ç¨¬™1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨, hopefully the situation will be much better, and we can look forward to a safe and orderly opening of schools.
This would mean that Term 3 will be very long. So we will factor in an additional one week, mid-term break √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 20-26 July√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. The additional break of one week will reduce curriculum teaching time. We will therefore also make certain topics commonly taught by all schools at the end of the academic year be non-examinable. This will reduce the curriculum load and ease the pressure off teachers and students in catching up with the curriculum.
We will do two other things during the brought forward mid-year holidays:
First, our graduating cohorts need support so as to prepare for their national exams. For this coming mid-year holidays, our schools will continue to have them come back to school for face-to-face consultation and coaching when the national situation improves √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú which we are confident will be the case.√¢‚Ç¨¬®Second, there is also another group that needs support √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú children of essential workers and vulnerable students. They have been coming back to school during the circuit breaker period.  Our schools will remain open for them throughout the mid-year holidays, to support them and their families.
It has been a topsy-turvy few months as the health situation has been very fluid and uncertain. I thank everyone for your hard work and co-operation.  We shall overcome the virus.
And to all our students, I am very sorry bubble tea shops will be closed.
Comments: Sir, may I ask if MOE related internships will be moved to June as well. As I have a scheduled internship at HQ CPDD in May.

Post Description:
The Government has announced tighter measures during the circuit breaker period and extended it √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 4 May 2020 to 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨.
This will have implications on education. Do we extend HBL by another four weeks?
Our teachers, students and parents have been working hard to make HBL work. It hasn√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t been easy. The learning curve is steep for everyone. I thank everyone for your hard work, perseverance, patience and positivity. 
HBL is a fall back when schools are suspended; it cannot be a prolonged substitute for school. It is better to let everyone have a break from this intense period. 
MOE will therefore bring forward the June holidays to start √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 5 May until 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. By √¢‚Ç¨¬™1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨, hopefully the situation will be much better, and we can look forward to a safe and orderly opening of schools.
This would mean that Term 3 will be very long. So we will factor in an additional one week, mid-term break √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 20-26 July√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. The additional break of one week will reduce curriculum teaching time. We will therefore also make certain topics commonly taught by all schools at the end of the academic year be non-examinable. This will reduce the curriculum load and ease the pressure off teachers and students in catching up with the curriculum.
We will do two other things during the brought forward mid-year holidays:
First, our graduating cohorts need support so as to prepare for their national exams. For this coming mid-year holidays, our schools will continue to have them come back to school for face-to-face consultation and coaching when the national situation improves √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú which we are confident will be the case.√¢‚Ç¨¬®Second, there is also another group that needs support √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú children of essential workers and vulnerable students. They have been coming back to school during the circuit breaker period.  Our schools will remain open for them throughout the mid-year holidays, to support them and their families.
It has been a topsy-turvy few months as the health situation has been very fluid and uncertain. I thank everyone for your hard work and co-operation.  We shall overcome the virus.
And to all our students, I am very sorry bubble tea shops will be closed.
Comments: Thank you for taking care of the children of essential workers and vulnerable children. Thank you for keeping the good humour. üòä When the going gets tough, the tough gets going.

MOE will therefore bring forward the June holidays to start √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 5 May until 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. By √¢‚Ç¨¬™1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨, hopefully the situation will be much better, and we can look forward to a safe and orderly opening of schools.
This would mean that Term 3 will be very long. So we will factor in an additional one week, mid-term break √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 20-26 July√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. The additional break of one week will reduce curriculum teaching time. We will therefore also make certain topics commonly taught by all schools at the end of the academic year be non-examinable. This will reduce the curriculum load and ease the pressure off teachers and students in catching up with the curriculum.
We will do two other things during the brought forward mid-year holidays:
First, our graduating cohorts need support so as to prepare for their national exams. For this coming mid-year holidays, our schools will continue to have them come back to school for face-to-face consultation and coaching when the national situation improves √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú which we are confident will be the case.√¢‚Ç¨¬®Second, there is also another group that needs support √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú children of essential workers and vulnerable students. They have been coming back to school during the circuit breaker period.  Our schools will remain open for them throughout the mid-year holidays, to support them and their families.
It has been a topsy-turvy few months as the health situation has been very fluid and uncertain. I thank everyone for your hard work and co-operation.  We shall overcome the virus.
And to all our students, I am very sorry bubble tea shops will be closed.
Comments: Good evening,is it possible for a bubble tea treat after Olevels.üòÇ

It has been a topsy-turvy few months as the health situation has been very fluid and uncertain. I thank everyone for your hard work and co-operation.  We shall overcome the virus.
And to all our students, I am very sorry bubble tea shops will be closed.

Post Description:
The Government has announced tighter measures during the circuit breaker period and extended it √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 4 May 2020 to 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨.
This will have implications on education. Do we extend HBL by another four weeks?
Our teachers, students and parents have been working hard to make HBL work. It hasn√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢t been easy. The learning curve is steep for everyone. I thank everyone for your hard work, perseverance, patience and positivity. 
HBL is a fall back when schools are suspended; it cannot be a prolonged substitute for school. It is better to let everyone have a break from this intense period. 
MOE will therefore bring forward the June holidays to start √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 5 May until 1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. By √¢‚Ç¨¬™1 Jun 2020√¢‚Ç¨¬¨, hopefully the situation will be much better, and we can look forward to a safe and orderly opening of schools.
This would mean that Term 3 will be very long. So we will factor in an additional one week, mid-term break √¢‚Ç¨¬™from 20-26 July√¢‚Ç¨¬¨. The additional break of one week will reduce curriculum teaching time. We will therefore also make certain topics commonly taught by all schools at the end of the academic year be non-examinable. This will reduce the curriculum load and ease the pressure off teachers and students in catching up with the curriculum.
We will do two other things during the brought forward mid-year holidays:
First, our graduating cohorts need support so as to prepare for their national exams. For this coming mid-year holidays, our schools will continue to have them come back to school for face-to-face consultation and coaching when the national situation improves √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú which we are confident will be the case.√¢‚Ç¨¬®Second, there is also another group that needs support √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú children of essential workers and vulnerable students. They have been coming back to school during the circuit breaker period.  Our schools will remain open for them throughout the mid-year holidays, to support them and their families.
It has been a topsy-turvy few months as the health situation has been very fluid and uncertain. I thank everyone for your hard work and co-operation.  We shall overcome the virus.
And to all our students, I am very sorry bubble tea shops will be closed.
Comments: Does this apply to polytechnics too?

Post Description:
Responding to a question on whether there was a certain number of cases that would trigger another round of circuit breaker measures, Gan Kim Yong emphasised the government would look at the specific nature of the cases, and that the main concern would be to keep clusters under control. This would result in more targeted interventions.

With regards to a nationwide circuit breaker where only essential activities are allowed, he said it is "unlikely to return to that scenario. "

Post Description:
"Grandparents and parents, please stay at home. Don't go visiting your children, because we do want to keep you safe at home." .
.
After the CB ends on Jun. 1, up to 2 people from each household will be able to visit parents or grandparents staying elsewhere once a day, according to Health Minister Gan Kim Yong. However, seniors are advised not to leave their homes to visit family members.

He added that for seniors who have no children, exceptions will be made on appeal basis where their siblings or nieces and nephews can visit them.

Post Description:
These same penalties could also be slapped on a slew of other work place violations that have been introduced to prevent the spread of Covid-19.
